hey Megan what are the challenges to

intestinal system has three lines of
Defense's and so first it has very
highly acidic stomach acids that will
cause proteins to unravel or denature
and then once that happens there are set
of enzymes in our stomachs that will
then chop those proteins up basically
our digestive system sees large proteins
like insulin or other kinds of drug

mucus layer and that basically is
another way that the stomach and small
intestine holds any molecules at arm's

intestinal lining and then if they do
happen to even run that gauntlet that
far the cells of the small intestine are
tightly packed together which makes it
really really hard for anything to get
through what did previous pill
formulations of insulin look like well
there's been lots of different attempts
and and not just with insulin but with
many kinds of molecules in one of the
ways they try to do this or with other
chemical components that they add to
them these are called permeation
enhancers and basically they cause the
cells and the intestinal lining to
separate a little bit and allow those
biologics then to wiggle in but they
tend not to be very effective for
anything as large as insulin they work
better on very small proteins called
peptides now I think what we're seeing
is a couple of different lines of
research one is building on these
permeation enhancers and they're doing a
couple of things
they add other components to them to
hide the molecules hide these large

then they also have compounds in them

one where researchers are trying to put
all those pieces together to protect
their biological molecules then they're
also taking this more engineering

that does is it just injects insulin in

they've shown that it can work as well
as a subcutaneous injection how does the

so it's pretty cool so what they do is
they've designed a little hollow pill
that it sort of looks like an acorn

highly curved top right so no matter how
